questions.text: During the surgical repair of a hiatal hernia, the celiac branch of the posterior vagal trunk was severed accidentally. The damage to this nerve would affect the muscular movements, as well as some secretory activities, of the gastrointestinal tract (GI). Which segment is least likely to be affected by the nerve damage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The vagus nerve supplies parasympathetic fibres to all of the abdominal organs, which receive blood from the celiac trunk or superior mesenteric artery.
  • Thus, the vagus supplies the foregut and midgut, extending distally to the junction of the midgut and hindgut, which is the right 2/3rd of the transverse colon.
  • While the hindgut from the left 1/3rd of the transverse colon to the rectum and pelvic viscera receives parasympathetic nerve supply from the Pelvic splanchnic nerves (Nervi Ergentes).
  • So, the ascending colon, cecum, jejunum, and ileum would all be affected by damage to the vagus nerve. The sigmoid colon, which receives parasympathetic innervation from the pelvic splanchnics, would not be affected.

questions.text: You are observing an operation to remove the left suprarenal gland. To expose the gland, the surgeon mobilises the descending colon by cutting along its lateral attachment to the body wall and dissecting medially in the fusion fascia behind it. Suddenly, the operative field is filled with blood. The surgeon realises he has failed to cut a mesenteric attachment between the left colic flexure and another organ. As a result of the traction, the surface of the organ tore. Which organ was injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The spleen is an intraperitoneal organ that is attached to the left colic flexure. It could tear if there was too much traction while pulling the descending colon away from the body wall. Another clue in this scenario that points to a ruptured spleen is the large amount of blood that fills the operative field. The spleen is covered by a very thin capsule, and it has a soft and pulpy parenchyma. So, when it is ruptured, the spleen bleeds profusely.

  • Peritoneal ligaments consist of two layers of the peritoneum that connect two organs or attach an organ to the body wall and may form part of an omentum. They are usually named after the structures being connected.
  • For example, the splenorenal ligament connects the left kidney to the spleen, and the gastrophrenic ligament connects the stomach to the diaphragm.

Explanation of other options :

Duodenum (Option A), Liver (Option C): The duodenum and liver are not associated with the left colic flexure.

Kidney (Option B): The kidney and suprarenal glands are retroperitoneal organs that are not associated with any mesenteric attachment.

questions.text: A patient presented with a swollen spleen, which protruded medially toward the umbilicus in the abdomen. A vertical and downward expansion of the spleen was resisted by the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The phrenicocolic ligament is a peritoneal fold connecting the splenic flexure of the colon to the diaphragm, which prevents downward expansion of the spleen.
  • The left colic flexure, also called the splenic flexure, is the point where the colon takes a sharp downward turn.
  • This flexure is the point where the transverse colon ends and the descending colon begins. It is located immediately inferior to the spleen, so an enlarged spleen must move medially to avoid this colic flexure.
  • The stomach lies medial to the spleen, and the tail of the pancreas inserts into the hilum of the spleen. These organs would not prevent the spleen from descending inferiorly.
  • The kidney and left renal artery are retroperitoneal organs; they would not obstruct the movement of the spleen.

Peritoneal ligaments of the spleen :

The peritoneal connections of the spleen anchor it in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen. They include the following:

  • Phrenicocolic ligaments
  • Gastrosplenic ligament
  • Splenorenal ligament

Explanation of other options :

Splenorenal ligament (Option B): Anchors the spleen to the posterior abdominal wall (limits posterior mobility).

Gastrosplenic ligament (Option C): Connects the spleen to the stomach (contains short gastric vessels).

Transverse mesocolon (Option D): Supports the transverse colon but does not restrict splenic movement.

questions.text: During an emergency surgery, a chronic gastric ulcer that perforated the posterior wall of the stomach was revealed. Further exploration revealed that the ulcer was eroding a large artery running immediately posterior to the stomach. Which artery is the source of the life-threatening haemorrhage in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The splenic artery is a branch of the celiac trunk. It passes deep into the stomach and sends branches to the pancreas before reaching the spleen. If the posterior wall of the stomach erodes, gastric juices could damage the splenic artery, resulting in haemorrhage.

Ulcers on the posterior wall of the stomach are more likely to bleed, while ulcers on the anterior wall of the stomach are more likely to perforate.

Posterior relations of the stomach (Stomach bed) :

  • Left crus of the diaphragm
  • Left kidney
  • Left suprarenal gland
  • Spleen
  • Splenic artery
  • Pancreas (except tail)
  • Transverse mesocolon

Blood supply of stomach :

  • Left gastric artery - a branch of the celiac trunk; principal artery to the stomach.
  • Right gastric artery - a branch of the common hepatic artery
  • Right gastroepiploic artery - a branch of the gastroduodenal artery
  • Left gastroepiploic artery - a branch of the splenic artery
  • Short gastric artery - a branch of the splenic artery

Arterial supply of the stomach

Explanation of other options:

Gastroduodenal (Option A): The gastroduodenal artery lies behind the first portion of the duodenum. An ulcer in this portion of the duodenum might jeopardise the gastroduodenal artery.

Common hepatic (Option B): The common hepatic artery is a branch of the celiac trunk, which runs superior to the lesser curvature of the stomach.

Left gastroepiploic (Option C): The left gastroepiploic artery runs on the left side of the greater curvature of the stomach.

questions.text: Which of the following organs does not have direct anatomical contact with the splenic surface?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The jejunum lies medial and inferior to the spleen and has no anatomical contact with the splenic surface.

The visceral surface of the spleen has impressions from :

  • Stomach - gastric impression superiorly
  • Left kidney - renal impression inferiorly
  • Splenic flexure of the colon - medially
  • The tail of the pancreas touches the hilum of the spleen

questions.text: Which among the following is not a boundary of the marked structure shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked structure in the above figure is the epiploic foramen. The aorta is retroperitoneal, and it does not form a boundary of this foramen.

Epiploic foramen:

Also known as the Foramen of Winslow, it is a passageway between the greater peritoneal sac and the lesser peritoneal sac.

Boundaries :

  • Superiorly - caudate lobe of the liver
  • Inferiorly - the first part of the duodenum
  • Anteriorly - right free margin of lesser omentum (hepatoduodenal part)
  • Posteriorly - inferior vena cava

choices.text: Celiac branch of the posterior vagus
Hepatic branch of the anterior vagus

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with gastric ulcers undergoes a highly selective vagotomy. The surgeon carefully preserves the nerve fibres running along the lesser curvature of the stomach. Which nerve is deliberately spared during this procedure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In high selective vagotomy, the Nerve of Latarjet is preserved, which runs along the lesser curvature of the stomach in the lesser omentum.

  • Nerve supply of stomach :
  • The stomach receives parasympathetic innervation from the vagus nerve and sympathetic innervation from the greater splanchnic nerve.
  • The vagus nerve helps in gastric emptying, while the greater splanchnic nerve helps in gastric filling.
  • The stomach receives dual vagal innervation from :
    • Anterior vagal trunk (from left vagus)
    • Posterior vagal trunk (from right vagus)
  • Branches of the anterior vagal trunk :
    • Hepatic branch - Supplies liver, extra biliary system, pylorus
    • Gastric branch - Gives rise to the anterior Nerve of Latarjet
  • Branches of the posterior vagal trunk :
    • Coeliac branch - Contributes to the coeliac ganglion
    • Gastric branch - Gives rise to the posterior Nerve of Latarjet
    • Criminal nerve of Grassi - The Main nerve involved in acid secretion. Nerve of Grassi, if missed during vagotomy, can result in the recurrence of gastric ulcers.
  • Anterior and posterior gastric branches of the Nerve of Latarjet resemble a crow's foot. It helps in gastric emptying. In high selective vagotomy, the Nerve of Latarjet is preserved, and as the nerve supply to the pylorus is preserved, gastric emptying is not affected. While in truncal vagotomy, the entire trunk is removed and will require pyloroplasty to avoid antral stasis.

questions.text: During an emergency splenectomy, the surgeon accidentally tore the gastrosplenic ligament. The artery (s) likely to be damaged in this event are:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The short gastric arteries run through the gastrosplenic ligament and are likely to be damaged if the ligament is torn during surgery.

  • The short gastric arteries are branches of the splenic artery near the hilum of the spleen.
  • The gastrosplenic ligament extends between the stomach and spleen and is a derivative of the dorsal mesogastrium.
  • The short gastric arteries and left gastroepiploic arteries run through the gastrosplenic ligament.

Explanation for other options:

Left gastric (Option A): The left gastric artery is a branch of the celiac trunk, which supplies the left half of the lesser curvature. It is the principal artery to the stomach.

Splenic (Option B): The splenic artery passes within the lienorenal ligament to reach the splenic hilum. The lienorenal ligament also contains the tail of the pancreas.

Middle colic (Option D): The middle colic artery is a branch of the superior mesenteric artery, which supplies the transverse colon.

questions.text: While performing an emergency laparotomy to control haemorrhage resulting from an arterial erosion caused by a duodenal ulcer, surgeons ligated the gastroduodenal artery near its origin. Assuming normal vascular anatomy, in which of the following arteries would now receive retrograde flow from collateral sources?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

If the gastroduodenal artery and its branches were ligated, blood would flow in a retrograde direction from the left gastroepiploic artery, which is a branch of the splenic artery, to the right gastroepiploic artery, a ligated branch of the gastroduodenal artery. This flow from the left to right gastroepiploic artery would allow blood to reach the entire greater curvature of the stomach.

  • The short gastric arteries are branches of the splenic artery, which supply the fundus of the stomach.
  • The left gastric artery is a branch of the celiac trunk, which supplies the left portion of the lesser curvature.

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with a bleeding ulcer of the lesser curvature of the stomach, which artery is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The left gastric artery is the artery that supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach (along with the right gastric artery). These two arteries would be most likely to cause bleeding at the lesser curvature of the stomach.

Blood supply of stomach :

  • Left gastric artery - a branch of the celiac trunk; the principal artery to the stomach.
  • Right gastric artery - a branch of the common hepatic artery
  • Right gastroepiploic artery - a branch of the gastroduodenal artery
  • Left gastroepiploic artery - a branch of the splenic artery
  • Short gastric artery - a branch of the splenic artery

Arterial supply of the stomach

Explanation of other options :

Gastroduodenal (Option A): The gastroduodenal artery is a branch off the common hepatic artery that supplies the duodenum, the head of the pancreas, and the greater curvature of the stomach.

Left gastro-omental (Option C), Right gastro-omental (Option D): The left and right gastro-omental (epiploic) arteries are the two arteries that supply the greater curvature of the stomach.

questions.text: Which is a derivative of the dorsal mesogastrium?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the options, only the greater omentum is a derivative of the dorsal mesogastrium.

  • During the development of the gut, the stomach is first seen as a fusiform dilatation of the foregut just distal to the oesophagus.
  • Its distal border is attached to the posterior abdominal wall by a fold of peritoneum called the dorsal mesogastrium. The ventral border is attached to the septum transversum by another fold of peritoneum called the ventral mesogastrium.
  • The organs spleen and pancreas develop in the dorsal mesogastrium, and the liver develops in the ventral mesogastrium.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with incessant crying and vomiting. During a full workup, delayed gastric emptying was identified. Which anatomical part of the stomach is affected by spasmodic contraction resulting in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above clinical scenario indicates infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which is characterised by a thickened pylorus.

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis:

  • Occurs due to idiopathic hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus and causes gastric outlet obstruction in early infancy.
  • This problem is more commonly seen in males. Symptoms like projectile vomiting appear several weeks after birth.
  • It is readily treated by dividing the thickened pyloric muscle (pyloromyotomy) without dividing the pyloric gastric mucosa.

questions.text: While performing a splenectomy (removal of the spleen) following a road traffic accident, the surgeons were keen to locate and preserve the tail of the pancreas, which is in close relation with:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The tail of the pancreas is closely related to the splenorenal ligament (marked D). The splenorenal ligament contains the tail of the pancreas and splenic vessels and is prone to injury during splenectomy.

  • The splenorenal ligament is the peritoneal structure that connects the spleen to the posterior abdominal wall over the left kidney.
  • The terminal portions of the splenic artery and vein, and, more inferiorly, the tail of the pancreas, lie between the two peritoneal layers of the splenorenal ligament. The tail of the pancreas can be injured during dissection when ligating and dividing the splenic vessels.
  • If the tail is injured, the pancreatic enzymes leak out and destroy the surrounding tissue, leading to chemical peritonitis or pancreatic fistula.

Explanation of other options:

Gastrosplenic ligament (marked C): Gastrosplenic ligament connects the spleen to the greater curvature of the stomach and contains the left gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels.

Inferior vena cava (Marked B): IVC is not directly related to the tail of the pancreas, while it lies posterior to the head of the pancreas.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not lie at least partially in the retroperitoneum?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The spleen is an intraperitoneal organ that is surrounded by visceral peritoneum on all sides and thus does not lie in the retroperitoneum.

The spleen is suspended in the visceral peritoneum by the gastrosplenic ligament and splenorenal ligament.

Explanation of other options:

First part of duodenum (Option A): The first part of the duodenum (Superior part) is partially intraperitoneal and partially retroperitoneal. The proximal 2.5 cm is intraperitoneal. The distal 2.5 cm is covered by peritoneum on its anterior and superior surfaces and forms the inferior boundary of the omental foramen (of Winslow)

Second part of duodenum (Option B): The Second part of duodenum (descending part) is covered by the peritoneum only on its proximal anterior surface and is thus entirely retroperitoneal.

Kidney (Option C): The kidneys and the suprarenal glands develop in the retroperitoneum and remain retroperitoneal.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman was broad-sided on the driver's side by an SUV and brought to the emergency department. On examination, she was hypotensive with tenderness along the left mid-axillary line and a swelling protruding downward and medially below the left costal margin. An X-ray revealed a fracture of the left 9th and 10th ribs near their angles. Which abdominal organ is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The spleen is the most likely organ that can be injured in this scenario because it lies deep to the ninth to eleventh ribs on the left side. Splenic rupture can cause hypotension, left-sided tenderness and swelling under the costal margin.

  • The spleen is a large, encapsulated, complex mass of vascular and lymphoid tissues situated in the upper left quadrant of the abdominal cavity between the fundus of the stomach and the diaphragm.
  • The spleen is located on the left posterolateral abdominal wall deep to the ninth to eleventh ribs on the left side.
  • Splenic injury can result from blunt trauma to the abdomen or rib fracture.

Surface marking of the spleen:

  • The long axis of the spleen corresponds to the long axis of the tenth rib.
  • The medial end of the spleen - Represented by a point 4 cm away from the midline at the level of the spine of the tenth thoracic vertebrae.
  • Lateral end of spleen - Represented by a point on the 10th rib in the midaxillary line.
  • The upper margin of the spleen corresponds to the upper margin of the 9th rib.
  • The lower margin of the spleen corresponds to the lower margin of the 11th rib.

Explanation of other options:

Descending colon (Option A): The descending colon extends from the left colic

Flexure in the left hypochondriac region to the level of the iliac crest. Although located on the left side, it lies lower in the retroperitoneum and is less vulnerable to being injured in a rib fracture.

Left kidney (Option B): Kidneys are retroperitoneal organs located on the posterior abdominal wall in the paravertebral gutter. The vertebral extent of the kidney is from the T12 vertebrae to the L3 vertebrae.

Pancreas (Option C): The pancreas is retroperitoneal except for the tail of the pancreas, which lies in the lienorenal ligament. The pancreas is less likely to be injured in rib fractures.
